comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: From: www.maritimequest.com/warship_directory/great_britain/bat... March 20, 1912: Launch of the Queen Mary at Palmer's Shipbuilding Ltd. Jarrow-on-Tyne, England. The end of the HMS Queen Mary: From www.battleships-cruisers.co.uk/hms_queen_mary.htm "During the battle of Jutland after receiving direct hits from the German ships Seydlitz and Derfflinger the Queen Mary blew up with the loss of 1,266 crew with only 9 survivors." The Battle of Jutland was May 31-June 1, 1916. The Queen Mary was sunk on May 31, according to www.worldwar1.co.uk/sunk16.htm

A lot of my family used to work at this shipyard and some still live in the area.

I remember going with my Grandfather in the sixties to see where he worked.

comment.author: 12814971@N00
comment._content: The first skipper of the Queen Mary was Reginald "Blinker" Hall. He instituted a number of reforms designed to ease the life of the enlisted crew- including installing the first ships library in the Royal Navy. He later became the director of Naval Intelligence during WWI and is generally regarded as one of the best ever in that role. He supported, and made use of, the radio intercept intelligence produced by Room 40- as the High Seas Fleet found out to their sadness at Jutland.
